source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: Corrosion of Zircaloy-4 is accelerated in water or steam above about 350°C when LiOH is present in sufficient concentrations
corrosion_data: accelerated rate (up to 100x pure water rate)

extra_properties.environment: LiOH solutions 310-415°C, Li up to 375 ppm

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: Kass [1] measured the corrosion and hydrogen pickup of Zircaloy-2 in concentrated LiOH solutions at 315 and 360°C

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: Murgatroyd and Winton [2] found the corrosion rate of Zircaloy-2 to increase significantly at 300°C in LiOH solutions
corrosion_data: 2x with 5 g/L LiOH, 100x with 72 g/L LiOH

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: Coriou et al. [3] investigated the effect of LiOH, NaOH, KOH, and NH4OH upon the corrosion of Zircaloy
corrosion_data: LiOH causes largest increase, NH4OH no effect

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: Hillner and Chirigos [5] found no effect of LiOH on the corrosion rate of Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4 for times up to 100 days at 360°C
corrosion_data: no effect at 0.002M, slight effect at 0.005M, large increases at ≥0.06M

extra_properties.alternative_salts: lower corrosion with LiNO3, Li2SO4, Li2CO3

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk1
evidence_span: McDonald et al. [6] measured the effect of LiOH on the corrosion rate of Zircaloy-4 at 316, 343 and 360°C
corrosion_data: enhanced corrosion at 0.01M LiOH approaching 100 days, rapid increase at 0.1M

extra_properties.lithium_saturation: 140 ppm in oxide at 0.01M, 900 ppm at 0.1M

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: Manolescu et al. [9] have compared the acceleration effect of LiOH on Zircaloy-2 and Zr-2.5Nb for 0.0005M to 1M LiOH solutions

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: Manolescu et al. [9] have compared the acceleration effect of LiOH on Zircaloy-2 and Zr-2.5Nb for 0.0005M to 1M LiOH solutions

evidence_span: Activation energy of oxidation rate constants

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk4
evidence_span: Hydrogen pickup fraction for samples exposed to LiOH solutions

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk4
evidence_span: Comparison of corrosion resistance of zirconium-based alloys in autoclave tests
composition_raw: with some iron or chromium or both
conditions: steam and accelerated LiOH autoclave tests

extra_properties.test_correlation: LiOH tests showed no correlation with steam tests, 415°C test not strongly correlated to long term 400°C test
extra_properties.niobium_alloy_sensitivity: niobium-containing alloys appear to be especially sensitive to the accelerating effect of LiOH
extra_properties.tin_effect: addition of tin appears to reduce this sensitivity

STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: The corrosion rate was observed to depend linearly upon time at the high LiOH concentrations with high hydrogen pickup as previously reported
conditions: high LiOH concentrations, high hydrogen pickup

extra_properties.oxide_layer_structure: outer porous layer + inner dense layer

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: at 400°C the weight gains were about 14 mg/dm² in water and in the 375 ppm Li solution with a pH of 10.3

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: When the pH of the solution was 12.4, the weight gains were over 400 mg/dm²

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: Tests were run at 400°C with NaOH and KOH solutions at 23000 and 39000 ppm of Na and K, respectively
corrosion_data: similar to 375 ppm Li (NaOH), no acceleration (KOH)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: Alloys containing niobium are very susceptible to the accelerating effect of LiOH

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk6
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4 in an autoclave is representative of in-reactor performance if the autoclave conditions include lithium contents of 75 to 180 ppm (present as LiOH) and the temperature range of 380 to 410°C

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_037_chunk7
evidence_span: McDonald et al. observed that there was no apparent pretransition region for Zircaloy corrosion in 0.1 M LiOH solutions

extra_properties.corrosion_behavior: linear kinetics observed early in the corrosion process
